subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized Test Case example
msgSnippet: ... Could you explain what overriding runTest() buys you over using something obvious like: public void testCalculateAge() { assertEquals(new
messageBody:
On Nov 20, 2003, at 2:19 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> This is what I mean by a parameterized test case. The feature
> "calculate
> a person's age by a given date." Each test is a single assertion, but
> since only the data changes, this test is data-driven, rather than
> duplicating the invocation of "getAgeAsOf()" in five tests.
>
> -------------------
> package ca.bluejays.scouting.amateur.model.test;
>
> import java.util.Date;
>
> import junit.framework.*;
> import XXX.BiographicalReport;
> import XXX.PlayerFactory;
>
> import com.diasparsoftware.java.util.DateUtil;
>
> public class CalculateAgeTest extends TestCase {
> private int expectedAge;
> private Date futureDate;
>
> public CalculateAgeTest(String testName, int expectedAge,
> Date futureDate) {
>
> super(testName);
> this.expectedAge = expectedAge;
> this.futureDate = futureDate;
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("Calculate Age");
> suite.addTest(new CalculateAgeTest("birthday", 30, DateUtil
> .makeDate(2004, 5, 4)));
> suite.addTest(new CalculateAgeTest("day before birthday", 29,
> DateUtil.makeDate(2004, 5, 3)));
> suite.addTest(new CalculateAgeTest("day after birthday", 30,
> DateUtil.makeDate(2004, 5, 5)));
> suite.addTest(
> new CalculateAgeTest("date of birth", 0, DateUtil
> .makeDate(1974, 5, 4)));
> suite.addTest(
> new CalculateAgeTest("invalid future date", 0,
> DateUtil
> .makeDate(1974, 5, 3)));
> return suite;
> }
>
> protected void runTest() throws Exception {
> BiographicalReport biographicalReport = PlayerFactory
> .makeBiographicalReport("Joe", "Rainsberger", DateUtil
> .makeDate(1974, 5, 4));
>
> assertEquals(new Integer(expectedAge), biographicalReport
> .getAgeAsOf(futureDate));
> }
> }

Could you explain what overriding runTest() buys you over using
something obvious like:

public void testCalculateAge() {
assertEquals(new Integer(expectedAge),
biographicalReport.getAgeAsOf(futureDate));
}

where biographicalReport is an instance variable initialized in
setUp(). As each run of the test method will be data-driven as
intended, it would appear to do the same thing.

I'm guessing it has something to do with not wanting to create a
BiographicalReport instance on every test method. At any rate, it
seems to be reaching fairly deep in the trick bag and I'm wondering
what I'm missing with the obvious approach.

Mike
